title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions for disparities in polling place availability. Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents to be treated as valid forms of identification for voting purposes. The Attorney General may take actions, including against States, in the name of the United States. Tribal identification documents issued by Native Corporations under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act can be used as valid identification for voting. The Attorney General has the authority to take legal actions, including against States, to address disparities in voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes. The Attorney General can take legal action, including seeking declaratory judgment or injunctive relief, to address disparities in voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes. This may involve increasing polling place availability to reduce disparities. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction over such actions, heard by a three-judge court. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction over actions to address disparities in voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes. The court of three judges will expedite the case, with a presumption that such disparities result in a denial or abridgement of rights. The Supreme Court judges assigned to hear voting disparity cases must expedite the process. There is a presumption that such disparities deny voting rights based on race or color. An aggrieved person can bring an action despite this presumption. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include protections for Indian reservations, requiring approval for activities like eliminating polling places or moving them further away. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 now includes protections for Indian reservations, requiring approval for actions like eliminating or moving polling places further away on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 protects Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions like moving or eliminating polling places on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 protects Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions like eliminating in-person voting, removing early voting locations, or decreasing voting hours on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 protects Indian reservations by preventing actions that reduce early voting opportunities or change voting dates on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 protects Indian reservations by ensuring early voting opportunities are not reduced or voting dates changed on reservations. Amendments include defining 'Indian reservation' and expanding the scope of activities covered under the Act. Federal election oversight on Indian reservations is addressed in Section 4. Section 8 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if a written complaint is received regarding potential voter discrimination based on race or color. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations in response to complaints of potential voter discrimination based on race or color. SEC. 5 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 regarding the termination of election observers. It specifies the conditions for the termination of observers appointed under subsection (b) of section 8. SEC. 6 provides definitions. SEC. 6 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 amends definitions related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations, specifying the meaning of terms like 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' as defined in relevant acts. SEC. 7 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to update bilingual election requirements and the definition of Indian reservation. Subsection (b)(3)(C) now references the year 2010 instead of 1990, and subsection (c) clarifies language requirements based on the date materials are provided. The Attorney General must release reports of Federal election observers within 6 months. The Attorney General should consult with tribal organizations annually on voting issues for Indian tribes.
